item.title: By: Martin
item.dc:creator: Martin
item.description:
It's very interesting - I had a quick look over the weekend. And it's near time for a re-read, so this might be as good a time as any.
I read a piece about the Lord of the Rings recently that rang true - namely, that Tolkien was writing myth (with added narrative detail) rather than an actual narrative-type novel. It puts criticism, and experience of, the book in a fresh perspective, I think. After all, it doesn't necessarily work as a novel, but as a detailed telling of a mythic story it is now the modern Western archetype. That's what later fantasy blockbusters have been trying to (and largely failing to) match over the years.
And yes, he's a fine writer. People forget he was a teacher of Anglo-Saxon literature as well as philology. And Anglo-Saxon and Norse literature/sagas are hugely rich in alliteration, contrasts of nature and the works of man, repetition, etc.
